title: Molecular Medicine
requirements: For research postgraduate students in Faculty of Medicine (Except Division of Nursing)
description: This joint course will give an introduction to basic concepts as well as modern techniques and technologies in Molecular Medicine.
outcome: 1.     To obtain basic knowledge of chromosomal abnormalities in tumour cells, methods for detection and their clinical significance2.     To discuss the genetic basis of cancer and implications for clinical diagnosis, prognostication and disease monitoring3.     Special topics in neuroscience/cancer biology: to focus on neuronal signaling and neurodegenerative diseases, and cell cycle control4.     Cell signaling: to discuss the concept and techniques used in signal transduction study and its connection with cancer5.     To obtain basic knowledge in molecular diagnostics6.     To obtain basic concepts on the design of molecular medicine studies, including statistical considerations7.     To obtain basic knowledge on high throughput molecular technologies, including those used in proteomics and the mass spectrometric analysis of nucleic acids
syllabus: Current usages of molecular diagnostic tests will be discussed and cancer will be used as a disease model in most of the examples covered in the course. Specific course objectives in relation to the topics covered are as follows: To obtain basic knowledge of chromosomal abnormalities in tumour cells, methods for detection and their clinical significance  To discuss the genetic basis of cancer and implications for clinical diagnosis, prognostication and disease monitoring Special topics in neuroscience/cancer biology: to focus on neuronal signaling and neurodegenerative diseases, and cell cycle control Cell signaling: to discuss the concept and techniques used in signal transduction study ad its connection with cancer To obtain basic knowledge in molecular diagnostics To obtain basic concepts on the design of molecular medicine studies, including statistical considerations To obtain basic knowledge on high throughput molecular technologies, including those used in proteomics and the mass spectrometric analysis of nucleic acids.
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher.
recommended_readings: The recommended readings will be suggested by the respective teacher during the lectures.

title: Biostatistics I (MED)
requirements: For research postgraduate students in Faculty of Medicine (Except Division of Nursing)
description: This course covers descriptive statistics, graphical methods, probability, probability distributions (normal, binomial and Poisson), sampling error, confidence intervals and basic hypothesis testing methods including the t-tests and chi-square tests.
outcome: Students should be able to:1.      Comprehend basic biostatistics appearing in medical literature 2.      Conduct basic biostatistics analysis including summary statistics and tests by the SPSS 3.      Write concise reports and interpretation of basic biostatistics analysis results
syllabus: This course will cover below topics: Exploration of data and probability distributions Population, sampling and confidence Intervals Hypothesis testing I Hypothesis testing II

title: Biostatistics II (MED)
requirements: For research postgraduate students in Faculty of Medicine (Except Division of Nursing)
description: This course covers ANOVA methods including one-way, two-way and repeated measures ANOVA, non-parametric hypothesis testing methods, correlation, linear regression and logistic regression.
outcome: Students should be able to:1.      Comprehend basic biostatistics appearing in medical literature 2.      Conduct basic biostatistics analysis including summary statistics and tests by the SPSS 3.      Write concise reports and interpretation of basic biostatistics analysis results
syllabus: This course will cover below topics:  ANOVA I ANOVA II / Nonparametric tests Correlation / Linear regression I Linear regression II / Logistic Regression
recommended_readings: Dawson and Trapp, Basic and Clinical Biostatistics, Lange 4th edition
